message.content:
We must first look at all transactions and “pick out” only those that represent investing cash flows. In our setting the “investing” items are those that reflect purchases (outflows) or sales (inflows) of long‐term assets. (Note that initial noncash “Fixed Assets” do not result in a “cash” flow during the period.) In our list many rows are “Purchase…” or “Fixed Assets Purchase” (together with “Sale…” of heavy equipment) that concern heavy equipment or heavy machinery. We must also “exclude” items that (a) are operating/administrative/expense/interest (b) are not “paid” in cash (for example, if the Payment/Receipt status is “Unpaid” or if the receive method is “Account Receivable”). Then we “sum up” all the cash amounts “paid for” fixed asset purchases (a negative cash impact) and “received” when a fixed asset is sold (a positive cash impact).

Let’s step‐through the list briefly:

────────────────────────────
1. (Row 4) Purchase20231231001 (“Heavy Equipment D”, 1.0 @1,500,000): paid by Bank Transfer → cash outflow: –1,500,000.0  
2. (Row 8) FixedAsset20231231001 (“Fixed Assets Purchase” of amount 886,161.25): outflow –886,161.25  
3. (Row 9) Purchase20231231002 (“Heavy Equipment A”, 1.0 @500,000): outflow –500,000.0  
4. (Row 13) Purchase20231231003 (“Heavy Equipment B”, 2.0 @800,000): amount = 1,600,000.0 outflow  
5. (Row 23) Purchase20231231005 (“Heavy Equipment C”, 1.0 @1,000,000): outflow –1,000,000.0  
6. (Row 26) Purchase20231231006 (“Heavy Equipment C”, 2.0 @1,000,000): outflow –2,000,000.0  
7. (Row 22) Sale20240106004 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment A, 1.0, amount = 748,087.14, paid in Cash): inflow +748,087.14  
8. (Row 29) Sale20240108006 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment D, 1.0, amount = 2,146,535.22, paid in Cash): inflow +2,146,535.22  
9. (Row 33) Purchase20231231007 (“Heavy Equipment A”, 2.0 @500,000): outflow –1,000,000.0  
10. (Row 44) Purchase20231231008 (“Heavy Equipment B”, 2.0 @800,000): outflow –1,600,000.0  
11. (Row 51) Purchase20231231009 (“Heavy Equipment A”, 2.0 @500,000): outflow –1,000,000.0  
12. (Row 63) Sale20240119016 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment C, 1.0, amount = 1,348,068.18, paid in Cash): inflow +1,348,068.18  
13. (Row 70) Sale20240122019 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment A, 1.0, amount = 694,657.72, paid in Cash): inflow +694,657.72  
14. (Row 76) Sale20240124022 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment A, 1.0, amount = 677,364.56, paid in Cash): inflow +677,364.56  
15. (Row 79) Sale20240125024 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment D, 1.0, amount = 2,210,585.18, paid in Cash): inflow +2,210,585.18  
16. (Row 80) Purchase20231231010 (“Heavy Equipment A”, 1.0 @500,000): outflow –500,000.0  
17. (Row 83) Sale20240126025 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment A, 1.0, amount = 661,580.66, paid in Cash): inflow +661,580.66  
18. (Row 94) Purchase20231231012 (“Heavy Equipment D”, 1.0 @1,500,000): outflow –1,500,000.0  
19. (Row 97) Sale20240130031 (“Sale” of Heavy Equipment C, 1.0, amount = 1,492,870.6, paid in Cash): inflow +1,492,870.6  
20. (Row 103) FixedAsset20231231001 (“Fixed Assets Purchase” from Supplier 1, amount = 839,853.83): outflow –839,853.83  
21. (Row 104) Purchase20231231013 (“Heavy Equipment A”, 1.0 @500,000): outflow –500,000.0  
22. (Row 105) Purchase20231231014 (“Heavy Equipment C”, 1.0 @1,000,000): outflow –1,000,000.0  

Other rows where “Sale” transactions are marked “Unpaid” or “Account Receivable” are not yet cash received so we ignore them.

────────────────────────────
Now, summing the amounts:

Total cash outflows (negative amounts) =
 1500000.0  
+ 886161.25  
+ 500000.0  
+ 1600000.0  
+ 1000000.0  
+ 2000000.0  
+ 1000000.0  
+ 1600000.0  
+ 1000000.0  
+ 500000.0  
+ 1500000.0  
+ 839853.83  
+ 500000.0  
+ 1000000.0  
= Let’s add step‐by‐step:
• 1,500,000.0 + 886,161.25 = 2,386,161.25  
• + 500,000.0 = 2,886,161.25  
• + 1,600,000.0 = 4,486,161.25  
• + 1,000,000.0 = 5,486,161.25  
• + 2,000,000.0 = 7,486,161.25  
• + 1,000,000.0 = 8,486,161.25  
• + 1,600,000.0 = 10,086,161.25  
• + 1,000,000.0 = 11,086,161.25  
• + 500,000.0 = 11,586,161.25  
• + 1,500,000.0 = 13,086,161.25  
• + 839,853.83 = 13,926,015.08  
• + 500,000.0 = 14,426,015.08  
• + 1,000,000.0 = 15,426,015.08  

Total outflow = 15,426,015.08

Total cash inflows =
• Row 22: +748,087.14  
• Row 29: +2,146,535.22  
• Row 63: +1,348,068.18  
• Row 70: +694,657.72  
• Row 76: +677,364.56  
• Row 79: +2,210,585.18  
• Row 83: +661,580.66  
• Row 97: +1,492,870.6  
Now add step‐by‐step:
• 748,087.14 + 2,146,535.22 = 2,894,622.36  
• + 1,348,068.18 = 4,242,690.54  
• + 694,657.72 = 4,937,348.26  
• + 677,364.56 = 5,614,712.82  
• + 2,210,585.18 = 7,825,298.0  
• + 661,580.66 = 8,486,878.66  
• + 1,492,870.6 = 9,979,749.26  

Total inflow = 9,979,749.26

────────────────────────────
Net cash flow from investing activities = Total Inflows – Total Outflows  
  = 9,979,749.26 – 15,426,015.08  
  = –5,456,265.82 (approximately)

We can round to two decimals as –5456275.82.

────────────────────────────
Thus, our answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-5456275.82"
  }
}

This is the final net cash effect on investing activities.
